DOC.HEAD: Amnesia Victim Says She'll Stay in Nashville
DOC.TEXT: A woman who turned up here with amnesia says she'll spend the holidays in Nashville because she ``felt like a duck out of water'' during a recent trip to her Ohio hometown. Ruth Ellish will send presents to her family in Akron but stay in Nashville, where she's spent the past year in the care of a shelter for homeless women. ``I feel comfortable here,'' she said. ``I feel like this is where I belong. It's my home now; it's the only place I really know.'' The 50-year-old woman prefers to be called Kitty Jordan, a name she adopted during her mysterious memory loss. She said she's grateful her perplexing past was cleared up after 10 months. ``A lot of my prayers have been answered,'' Jordan said. She woke up in a Nashville motel Dec. 10, 1988, bruised and unable to remember her name or where she lived. After national publicity, she was reunited Oct. 4 with her mother, Irene Christ, and sister, Elise White, both of Ohio. White said the family believes her sister fled under stress when she was threatened by a boyfriend of her 18-year-old daughter. Since the reunion, Jordan has visited her former home, but said she still doesn't remember her earlier life. ``It was strange,'' she said of a November trip to Akron. ``I felt like a duck out of water. ... ``They know me, and the warmth they show me, well, I feel like they are family. But I don't really know them,'' she said. ``The best part about all of it was seeing the Nashville skyline when I was flying back.'' Jordan also has two sons, ages 20 and 29. Relatives said she was a computer analyst at the Alltel-Western Reserve Telephone Co. in Hudson, north of Akron. She works as a junior staff cook for room and board and $50 a week at a shelter for homeless women and children operated by the Nashville Union Rescue Mission. ``I am happy here,'' she said. ``I'm just hoping that in 1990 I will be able to get a full-time job with the mission, because I love my work here. ``Otherwise, if I have to, I'll try and get another job, perhaps as an administrative assistant or an executive secretary. I need to be making more money to start my own life. ``But I've got a lot to be thankful for.''
